lines.text: [first lines]
Hear! Hear! Hear! Court's called to order!

The figures in this story are familiar ghosts of my own boyhood. The War between the States was over, but its tragedies and comedies haunted every grown man's mind, and the stories that were swapped took deep root in my memory.

[Offering Priest a drink]
Have a snifter? Good corn!
You can smell the feet of the boy that ploughed it!

[to Bagby]
That breath of yours is like a hot mince pie.
That's sort of a novelty, Herman, - the barber gettin' cut up! Whoever cut him up couldn't have cut him up much if they used the barber's razor.
Your honor, as I recollect the procedure, at the time bein' I'm an ordinary member of the bar in good standing.
Not ordinary, sir, but absolutely in good standing.
Hey, hey boy, wake up there. Sheriff, wake him up there. If anybody's going to sleep in this court, it'll be me.
Hey, wake up.
What?
Come here, boy. Come on over here. What's your name?
Um, Jeff Poindexter.
Your honor. Your honor. Is this a court of law? I ask you, is this a court of law?

Oh, now, now, now, Senator, I wouldn't, I wouldn't, don't get on your high horse, that way. You know, we ain't in any great hurry, but, a, incidentally, but, what are you, what are your charged with, there boy?
Nothin' Judge. But, I wasn't there, them chickens, shaw nuff, I just fishin'
Fishin'? Where was you fishin'?
Down, sleepy river.
Here, come here, what, what do you use for bait?
Oh, I got hunk of beef liver.
Beef liver?

Yeah. Take the beef liver and put it on there and chuck it out there. Let them have the first piece, for nothin', see and then you put some more on there and chuck it out there and then they think they're going to get that for nothin' and then you catch 'em as long as you got the liver.
Praise the Lord, Mr. 'Rome! Is you in or is you in?
Hi, Aunt Dilsey!
How come you here? The Judge say you up there at that college learnin' to be a lawyer man.
Aunt Dilsey, I got stomach trouble.
Lord, help you, white child. What them Yankees been feedin' you?
Not a darn thing! That's the trouble. What have you got for supper?
Mr. 'Rome, you stay here. I is goin' to kill the high-steppin'ist rooster in the yard and a great big bowl of gravy and grits.
And waffles?
Don't you worry none, honey, you is home now.
Alright, come on with that beef liver, now.
Oh, the beef liver in the bait bag. I always keep it in here.
Hurry up now.
That liver?
Oh, gee, don't tell, don't tell me you ain't got it?
Looks like that liver done walked off by itself.
Lord, I ain't gonna catch any catfish if I ain't got no bait. Take this dime, now. Hurry on back to town and get me that beef liver.
Alright.
Hurry up, now.
Alright, sir. Actually runnin' now.
You gonna put your shoes on?
I gonna save 'em in case my feet wear out. Then, I have 'em.
As much sittin' around you do, it won't be your feet that will wear out.
I gotta have this good ole pretty vest, hangin' up in there, doin' nothin'.
By Grant, well, placate you, I thought I told you to stay away from that vest.
But, it just a got hung up on my arm.
And you got my coat on there, too!
Yes, but, this ole skunk coat
Skunk coat!
I mean possum.
What do you mean, possum?
A rabbit.
Rabbit? Say listen, every inch of that is raccoon. It better be raccoon. I took it off a rich Yankee.
What I'm worried about is this poor devil of a Gillis.
You know Gillis?
My trade takes me into queer quarters, sometimes.
Oh, Jeff! Jeff! Come on. Come on. Hurry up, here. Come on, here, when I holler at you. Where you been?
Yes sir, well, I was just, I was...
Say, listen. You want to, you want to earn that ole coon skin coat of mine?
I can have that coon coat jacket? Thank you.
Hey, yeah, wait a minute, come back here. You can, if you do everything I tell you to. Ah, do you know a gentleman by the name of Mr. Horace Maydew?
Yes sir, that mean man in that cold house.
Yeah. Well, now, you see that he gets that.
[Hands him an envelope]
But, don't let him know how it got there.
That's all I got to do? Thank you.
Say, wait a minute. Can, can you play Dixie on that thing, there?
With that coon coat, yes, I play Dixie with Marching Through Georgia.
Wait, hey, Marchin' Through Georgia? Yeah, I got you out of one lynchin'.
Yes, with that coon coat, I know I was going to get.
If I catch you playin' that Marchin' Through Georgia, I'll join the lynchers.
Reverend Brand, before you come to this town, what was your occupation?
In my early manhood, before I took holy orders, I had the honor to be a Captain of artillery in the late war.
In the war of the rebellion?
No sir. In the war for the Southern Confederacy.
My, my error.
